Indiana's backcourt scored a combined 49 points, too much for the visitors

IU hits 12 3s in 74-68 win over SMU

Zach Osterman, The Indianapolis Star 6:13 a.m. EST November 21, 2014

Nov 20, 2014; Bloomington, IN, USA; Indiana Hoosiers forward Hanner Mosquera-Perea (12) battles Southern Methodist Mustangs guard Sterling Brown (3) and center Yanick Moreira (2) for a rebound during the first half at Assembly Hall. Mandatory Credit: Pat Lovell-USA TODAY Sports(Photo: Pat Lovell / Pat Lovell-USA TODAY Sports)

CONNECT 1 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

BLOOMINGTON, Ind. – Indiana struggled with its greatest strength Thursday, but never strayed from it, shooting 33 3-pointers in a 74-68 win over No. 22 SMU.

The Hoosiers (3-0) endured cold stretches at the beginning of both halves, and they struggled all night to produce consistently around the rim. But they still hit 12 3s, providing nearly half of their points and proving once again that this Indiana team won't get gunshy with anyone.

SMU's (1-2) 19 turnovers canceled out the Mustangs' 40-27 advantage over Indiana on the boards. Indiana's backcourt scored a combined 49 points, too much for the visitors.

Freshman guard James Blackmon Jr., the nation's leading freshman scorer, finished with a game-high 26 points and a team-high seven rebounds. He never turned the ball over.

A jump-shots-only offense and an inability to keep SMU away from the offensive glass put Indiana in a hole early. The Mustangs ran off a 22-10 lead to start the game, at one point outrebounding IU 11-3.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Indiana basketball's Devin Davis 'heading home' from hospital

But sealing up the cracks of that defense — and avoiding costly turnovers — slowed SMU and opened for the Hoosiers an avenue back into the game.

Indiana forced 11 turnovers and only committed four in the opening 20 minutes of action. And after starting 1 of 5 from behind the arc in the first half, the Hoosiers found their shooting boots, hitting 6-of-13 from behind the 3-point line from there on.

    Blackmon paced all scorers with 14 points on 5-of-10 shooting in the opening half. Junior guard Yogi Ferrell had 10 points and three assists and his counterpart, SMU guard and Warsaw High School alum Nic Moore, finished the half with eight points, four assists and five rebounds.

    The overall performance of Indiana's backcourt balanced out a night of frustration from junior forward Hanner Mosquera-Perea, who finished with three points, one block and no rebounds.

    The Hoosiers suffered a similar dry shooting spell early in the second half, and midway through, SMU had rallied from a five-point halftime deficit to lead 50-46. Then Indiana's shooters drew breath again.

    Collin Hartman knocked down a corner 3-pointer. Nick Zeisloft sank a pair of long-range efforts, both of them created from clever guard play.

    When Zeisloft's second 3-pointer of that stretch slid home, Indiana had stretched the lead out to eight points and the Hoosiers looked capable of running away with a win.

    Instead, Moore and the Mustangs fought back, but ball security — not always Indiana's best attribute — helped the Hoosiers seal off their first ranked win of the season.
